captions.text:
One of the most exciting scientific findings
of the past half century has been the discovery
of widespread trophic cascades.

A trophic cascade is an ecological process
which starts at the top of the food chain
and tumbles all the way down to the bottom.

And the classic example is what happened in
the Yellowstone National Park

in the United States when wolves were reintroduced
in 1995.

Now, we all know that wolves kill various
species of animals, but perhaps we're slightly
less aware
that they give life to many others.

Before the wolves turned up - they'd been
absent for 70 years -

the numbers of deer (because there had been
nothing to hunt them) had built up and built
up in the Yellowstone Park
and despite efforts by humans to control them

they'd managed to reduce much the vegitation
there to almost nothing. They had just grazed
it away.

But as soon as the wolves arrived, even though
they were few in number
they started to have the most remarkable effects.

First, of course, they killed some of the
deer but that wasn't the major thing.

Much more significantly, they radically changed
the behavior of the deer.

The deer started avoiding certain parts of
the park - the places where they could be
trapped most easily -
particularly the valleys and the gorges
and immediately those places started to regenerate.

In some areas, the height of the trees quintupled
in just six years.

Bare valley sides quickly became forests of
aspen and willow and cottonwood.

And as soon as that happened, the birds started
moving in.

The number of songbirds and migratory birds
started to increase greatly.

The number of beavers started to increase
because beavers like to eat the trees.
And beavers, like wolves, are ecosystem engineers.
They create niches for other species.

And the dams they built in the rivers provided
habitats for otters and muscrats and ducks
and fish and reptiles and amphibians.

The wolves killed coyotes and as a result
of that, the number rabbits and mice began
to rise
which meant more hawks
more weasels
more foxes
more badgers

Ravens and bald eagles came down to feed on
the carrion that the wolves had left.

Bears fed on it, too. And their population
began to rise as well

partly also because there were more berries
growing on the regenerating shrubs.

And the bears reinforced the impact of the
wolves by killing some of the calves of the
deer.
But here's where it gets really interesting.
The wolves changed the behavior of the rivers.

They began to meander less. There was less
erosion.

The channels narrowed. More pools formed.
More riffle sections.
All of which were great for wildlife habitats.
The rivers changed in response to the wolves.

And the reason was that the regenerating forests
stabilized the banks so that they collapsed
less often.
So the rivers became more fixed in their course.

Similarly, by driving the deer out of some
places,

and the vegetation recovering on the valley
side,

there was less soil erosion because the vegitation
stabilized that as well.

So the wolves, small in number, transformed
not just the ecosystem of the Yellowstone
National Park

-This huge area of land... but also, its physical
geography.

How the wolves change rivers
 ENJOY THE SCENERY AND LEARN ABOUT YELLOWSTONE NATIONAL PARK ALSO!!!
 
How Wolves Change Rivers (fascinating!).  When wolves were reintroduced to 
Yellowstone National Park in the United States after being absent nearly
70 years, the most remarkable "trophic cascade" occurred.
What is a trophic cascade and how exactly do wolves change rivers?﻿

comments.author: tparbs

comments.text:
We are all interconnected, not only with each other but with everything. 
All in nature is alive, it’s life, and all beings on the planet give 
balance to various cycles mother Earth goes through. When we start 
jeopardizing these things, and we have, nature becomes out of balance, we 
do however have the potential to fix and restore the damage that we’ve done 
to our planet, but we must do it now. Now is our chance to change the 
direction we were previously heading.This video is a great example of what 
I am talking about.Take a look, and know the sacredness of all life and how 
it’s connected to everything else.It is our job as humans to protect 
it.Nature has all of the answers we need to see clearly. If we would just 
take the time to stop and observe, all of the answers we seek in life, all 
of the problems we currently face and all of the solutions we currently 
need exist within the nature of things on a collective and individual 
level.We were meant to exist in harmony with it, protect it, work with it, 
not against it and learn from it.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ysa5OBhXz-Q#t=256﻿

The people who believe this are extremely naive, the wolves have destroyed 
the ungulate species populations. Elk population in Yellowstone have gone 
from 19,000 elk in 1995 to 4000 in 2013. The moose population is relatively 
gone in Yellowstone. We look at wolves a see something that is so cute but 
in reality they are one of the most efficient predators in North America. 
If Wolf populations are not managed correctly the ungulate populations will 
be destroyed. ﻿

comments.author: Peter Brunet

comments.text:
If you want to control the deer herd wolves are one way to do it.  But I 
guarantee you there are enough hunters to do it also.  The Federal 
government would simply have to open the deer herd up to a heavier handed 
game management.   Interesting though to see what happened and how it might 
not have been predicted.  And a pleasant surprise and lesson to all types 
of naturalists for sure.  For myself, I'd prefer not to compete with wolves 
for the deer in Yellowstone or anywhere else.  The deer herd is the center 
of a way of life where I come from.  The roll that the whitetail deer plays 
in our lives cannot be understood by an America that doesn't partake and 
isn't dependent on this creature the way we are.  Wolves are cool, but the 
whitetail is the true king of the forest in my eyes.  Meanwhile, I 
appreciate the fact that most Americans are urbanites today so they will 
never experience the true understanding and loss of love for the wolf 
that rural Americans know about personally.  And sadly there are not enough 
ranchers and "live off the land" types of people to affect policy in this 
country today with regard to wolves or anything else.﻿

comments.text:
How the "Wolf" saved the world. I'm skeptical, VERY skeptical. first off 
calling ELK deer. Next the Wolves that were introduced were not ever native 
to Montana or Yellowstone they ARE a northern Canadian variety. Then there 
is the preposterous claim that in just 20 years all this evolved. 
CONCLUSION: propaganda pipe dream.
Next year don't forget to buy a Wolf tag and drop one for the team.﻿
comments.author: 2drsdan

comments.text:
This video isn't telling the correct story about the wolves.  Deer and Elk 
wouldn't be hard on the river banks.  Buffalo like cattle might.  This 
video would lead you to believe that adding the non native invasive species 
(timer wolf) to the ecosystem has been all sugar plumbs and fairies.  The 
elk and deer and moose populations in the park has declined not risen.  The 
deer, elk and moose have been decimated outside of the park.  Point in case 
would be the Bitteroot national forest.  Before the wolves 16000 elk and 
good moose populations.  Now 1000 elk and almost no moose.  The Montana 
wildlife service is so desperate to control the wolves they now have to 
dramatically decrease the wolf numbers by using helicopters to hunt them. 
 The revenue in the states that have wolves has cost hundreds of millions 
of dollars.  all for a non native invasive species.  The grey wolf would be 
the native wolf.  a totally different wolf an about half the size.  the 
timber wolf is from Canada.﻿
comments.author: Trent Haverfield

comments.text:
+Trent Haverfield did you even watch the video? They even show a deer 
grazing at the bank.
comments.author: rezargamer

comments.text:
I was talking about wolves in Yellowstone, not Bitterroot. I know nothing 
about Bitterroot national forest. If they did introduce timber wolves there 
then that was a dumb move. Ecosystems aren't adapted for invasive species. 
But the wolves in Yellowstone were grey wolves. Which is what this video 
was talking about in the first place. It would make sense that introducing 
an invasive species such as the timber wolf would cause elk populations to 
drop so drastically. But its not because they just added wolves, its 
because they added the wrong wolf. I am fairly certain that if they had 
reintroduced the proper species then the ecosystem would have 
re-stabilized, not cause such drastic population decline.
comments.author: Brooke R

comments.text:
I get the ecosystem will ebb and flow. But when hunting managed game 
numbers they didn't crash like that. The gray wolf was not what was 
introduced it's the timber wolf you are wrong. The native grey wasn't an 
option. It was take decades to restore the bitterroot elk population if 
wolves aren't there to stunt that...not mention the shiras moose which may 
be soon on the endangered list in the rockies.
comments.author: Trent Haverfield

comments.text:
+Trent Haverfield The wolves that were reintroduced into Yellowstone were 
the native grey wolves. And the elk population in Yellowstone is from about 
10000-20000 in the summer. Also populations of animals in an ecosystem ebb 
and flow. As numbers of wolves increase and numbers of elk decrease the 
wolves will find that there is less food. As a result they will begin to 
starve and die off, decreasing the population. This allows for the elk 
population to increase because there will be less predators. The ecosystem 
can control its own population, there is no need for human intervention.
